fields.description:
When I'm working hard, I always forget that I've got text typed into the search box. 

When I go to another program and come back to source tree, I've forgotten I've got a search term in there and I can't understand why none of my files are showing up.
Can you move the search box to the left, near the drop down to show what files are to appear?
fields.summary: Highlight or move search box

fields.description:
SourceTree doesn't always display latest status of local files. To make sure all changes are displayed, refresh (F5) must be pressed. This is very annoying and can lead  to problems if you forgot to manually refresh change-list before commit.
Many modern programs can properly (automatically) track changed files (e.g. Eclipse Luna) and SourceTree should too.
fields.summary: Automatically detect changes in files (aka auto refresh)

fields.description:
I have three commits I am interested in. When I select only one commit it shows me three modified files. If I select all three commits it is showing only two modified files. 

The main problem I see is that selecting only one commit shows some files and selecting more commits should show more data and not less data, so if this is not a bug at least this is counterintuitive.
fields.summary: when multiple commits are selected the list of modified files does not show all modified files

fields.description:
The "Open Selected Version" context menu in Log/History uses the default application for that file type, but with several development environments installed on my machine, this is not what I want - I actually want to open in a text editor.

Apparently there used to be (or maybe only on Mac version) an "Open With..." option (see https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1179)

Was this removed? Could it not easily be implemented? Or at least a "Save current version as" option?

I tried creating a Custom Action, but since it only uses $FILE, it is not available in the Log/History window.
fields.summary: "Open Selected Version" option in Log/History should not use default application

fields.description:
When a new file is being added, it's currently not possible to stage individual lines. 

However, if a new file is staged, then modified, the unstaged changes CAN be staged using hunks and/or lines, which makes the absence of the ability to stage lines initially even more confusing.

It should be possible to stage individual lines of a new file, and the use cases are identical to the ones for stage lines in an existing file.
fields.summary: Ability to stage/unstage lines of a new file

fields.description:
The interface is unusable when reviewing a large ( 4000+ files) past commit in the "Log/History" file.

Step to reproduce : Open a git repository. 
    Commit a large number of file at once.
    Review this commit through the "Log/History" pane.

Actual Result :The UX stays unresponsive for minutes but completes succesfully.

Expected result : better performances. Tortoisegit lists the same commit after a much shorter time, around 20 seconds.
fields.summary: UX hangs when displaying a large commit in "Log/History" pane

fields.description:

Then single-click on one of the selected items.
Per Windows UX convention, that single-click should change the selection to that item only. Currently, clicking in this way has no effect, leaving the entire group of previously selected items selected.

fields.description:

fields.description:
When committing, fairly often (but not every time) I receive the error:
{quote}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false commit -q -F C:\Users\Chad\AppData\Local\Temp\owdxgzw1.huk

*** Please tell me who you are.

Run


  git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
  git config --global user.name "Your Name"

to set your account's default identity.
Omit --global to set the identity only in this repository.

fatal: unable to auto-detect email address (got 'Chad@chad-acer.(none)')
{quote}

Repository Settings - Advanced shows "Use global user settings" checked, and the Full Name and Email address shown in gray are correct.

If I simply uncheck "Use global user settings", leaving Full Name and Email address unmodified, the commit succeeds.

I've seen this occur with multiple repos. It seems that while I may not get this error at first for a given repo, once this behavior starts it does not spontaneously resolve, even after restarting SourceTree.
fields.summary: Commit fails to find global credentials

fields.description:
When I'm developing a new feature for a forked github repo, I will often need to rebase my branch when the main repo gets updated so to keep my branch uptodate.

Once I've made the rebase, I need to push it to my repo.

Currently, there is no push -f option and I have to run from it from the Terminal.

That works, but the terminal doesn't know about my username/password for my repo and I have to re-enter it. Which is another pain.

Regards,

Richard Quadling.

fields.description:
Scenario: my (git) repo is set up with some kind of auth other than username and password (un/pw), but the setup isn't working for whatever reason. I try to push, pull, etc (some kind of server action). The set up auth fails, so git/SourceTree falls back to un/pw auth, prompting me for a password. Ok, makes sense, everything is good.

Problem: Well, instead of using un/pw auth, I'm going to cancel and fix my setup, then try again. Oh wait, canceling the un/pw auth doesn't really work. The dialog just pops up again. And again. And again. And again. About 10 times in total it seems.

In my particular scenario, my remote is 'git@mygitserver:myuser/myrepo.git'. I have one key pair set up for msysgit on the command line and one PuTTy key pair I use for SourceTree. I have pageant loading at login. But of course it doesn't load my key at launch, without tinkering with the shortcut. Whatever. The point is, key auth fails, so git/ST falls back to SSH un/pw auth, and thus prompts me for my un/pw. Except I don't have an SSH un/pw, so I cancel. But cancelling doesn't work unless I cancel it 6 or 8 or WAY TO MANY TIMES. I really should only have to cancel once. It's a 'Cancel' button. If you press the cancel button, it should CANCEL auth. WTF?
fields.summary: Cancel doesn't cancel authentication

fields.description:
The "diff" panel will remain blank when selecting commits a certain way.

*Steps to Reproduce:*
1.  Checkout a somewhat recent branch.
2.  Filter commit graph by "All Branches".
3.  Select an older unmerged branch from the Branches area that is different from the branch you have checked out.
4 - When the commit panel is updated and the branch is highlighted by Sourcetree in the graph panel, you may see the two left panels (log history and file summary) but you will NOT see the right panel which is supposed to show the actual file diff. The right panel will remain blank. Selecting a branch and looking at the commit the shows up will not show the diff. To see the issue, the user has to click to a different commit in the commit graph panel, then click back on the intended commit, then he will be able to see the diff.
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not show the anything in the "diff" panel on Checkout window

fields.description:
Using Git Flow-> Start new Hotfix, it only allows me to create from the latest master branch. Other options (working copy parent, specific commit) are greyed out.
One or both of these options would be useful when your "production" version is v3.0, you have built a "test" version for v3.1 (and "finished" release branch v3.1), but you then need to do a hotfix on v3.0. Since v3.1 is the last finished release, I can't create a hotfix on v3.0.
Hmm: thinking it through, is it expected that a "test" release branch (v3.1 here) is not git-finished until it goes to production? The only thing that doesn't cover is that there should be a tag for v3.1 even though it hasn't yet progressed from "test" to "production".
My workaround for now was to create a feature branch from the point of the v3.0 release.
fields.summary: gitflow - Allow hotfix from commit other than latest master

A worse problem, however, is that after the failed update, the previous embedded git isn't restored (I think), and I started to get a failure running sh.exe. SoureTree runs sh.exe quite often it seems, and so as soon as I push OK, I get the same error over and over.

Setting my git to system git didn't fix the repeating sh.exe error.
fields.summary: PortableGit.7z fails to extract, annoying repeating sh.exe error begins

fields.description:
Just create a new Repos, SourceTreee crashed and I cannot open anymore.

OK, got it! Analyzed the log an I can see "Illegal characters in path."

Unfortunately you cannot start SourceTree anymore any fix anything if you have this!

---
I have removed this line from opentabs.xml (see included):
<string>C:\Users\Public\Documents\Sync\Daten\GIT\pandoc.wiki</string>
and I could start again. Well!

Then I tried to add this local repository again (see pandoc.wiki.zip enclosed) and SourceTree crashed again. Origin of this WIKI repos is here: https://github.com/jgm/pandoc/wiki

May this all help you to identify the "illegal chars" which I expect to be in the repos and not in the config files.
fields.summary: Crash on start - Illegal characters in path.

fields.description:
If a user has several new working copy repositories on a given system, they can add it them to SourceTree by either:
 # Clone/New -> Add Working Copy
 # Menu -> Open -> Select a Single Folder
 # Drag-and-Drop Working Directory into SourceTree

If the user has multiple repositories for a project (for example, nine), the process is tedious unless they use option three (drag-and-drop). This option is not always user-intuitive. I think it would be ideal that the `Menu -> Open` action will allow the selection of multiple working copies and let the `Create Bookmarks?` dialog help the user with a multiple repository import.
fields.summary: Support the Importing/Bookmarking of Multiple Git Repositories via Menu

fields.description:
SourceTree is unable to authenticate using pageant as long as a private key is saved in Putty's default profile - even if it's the same (and only) key in use system-wide. I searched for three hours before finding this link: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/153759?src=search
I'm only using one private key, but i tried the suggestion anyway. Once I removed my key from the default profile, that same key works just fine through pageant. This is not a problem elsewhere - I have had no problem connecting with other git gui software using pageant with the same default profile, etc. - the *only* program that choked on it is SourceTree. But it makes no sense - if the default profile was overriding SourceTree's configuration or pageant's selected key, it would be overriding it with the exact same key (not a copy stored in another location - the exact same file). SourceTree also worked just fine when I converted my key to the OpenSSH format and changed SourceTree's configuration to use that method instead of putty - again, with the exact same key pair.
fields.summary: Unable to connect to repo using pageant for authentication

fields.description:
As working in a team, we will have more files that are unstaged. Among them if we want to stage some files it is difficult to search. Instead if a search box/filter box for unstaged and staged files list is provided in the client GUI, it will be helpful to search and stage files.

Search key can be part of file name and path like regular expression based search.
fields.summary: Search EditBox/Filter for unstaged and staged files list

fields.description: We're having issues where the latest update of SourceTree for Windows wipes user data (the display name and user email address) from the embedded Git config file. As a result, commits from devs are coming in as "unknown" with an automatically generated email instead of using the display name and email provided by the user. However, the user information displayed under Tools>Options remains correct, and all of the individual repositories are inheriting their user information from that global source (i.e. there are no custom display names for certain projects). This [Atlassian answer|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/148713/sourcetree-commit-author-change-update] resolved our issue, but the question remains: why is this happening at all? Is this just a bug for the current update of SourceTree, or will we have to use this workaround every time the software is updated?
fields.summary: updating SourceTree wipes user information

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
1. Add 2 repos on Sourcetree
2. On both repos, add identical subtree links
3. Subtree pull in repo 1 -> OK
4. Subtree pull in repo 2 -> nothing seems to happen
5. Back in to repo 1 -> the subtree has been pulled again here (doing nothing though, as the subtree is up to date since step 3)

In order to pull subtree in repo 2, SourceTree has to be restarted. Then, after pulling in repo 2, subtree can't be pulled in repo 1 - it triggers a pull in repo 2 instead.
fields.summary: Given 2 repos with identical subtree links, subtree pull only executes in the first repo where the subtree is used

fields.description:
Most of the time the interface is slow or freezes for up to 60 seconds at a time. Usually this happens when selecting items in the branch view, file status or push/pull summary.

I suspect this is happening when it is trying to create a preview of the changes inside the files.

The user input should have priority over this. Preferably creating the previews should run on a separate thread and be canceled / paused when the user changes the selection or opens / closes a window.

fields.description:
I select one commit in log list. I select modified file and watchig there for changes. Then I go to my IDE and change there something. Then open up ST again. Trying to scroll for more changes in that file. But ST refreshes log window, this action refreshes modified files list and the view with changes details text.
this is very annoying. why should ST refresh that data which will never be changed ? commit already made. its old commit. 

So following my logic, you should change your behaviour and dont refresh all views if I selected commited data. and vice versa if selected Uncommitted changes.

Moreover, sometimes log list refreshes three times and with linked views. Why should we reload all data everytime ? We're loaded old commits already. We dont need to refresh those rows. 

So there should be custom refreshable list component which refreshes only top data. above commited changes, above current date.

Thank you.
fields.summary: SourceTree refreshes list severail times with linked views

fields.description:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/10410461/answers/10410469

Just migrated my code from svn to git.

Committed and pushed the latest svn revision (clean start in git). It's around 2k files with a total size of about 20mb.

After push, i tried to see the log / history tab, but sourcetree hangs, and the memory skyrockets (i kill it in 2gb).

Same happens with every repository i migrated.

I'm using the latest version 1.6.10.0
fields.summary: sourcetree hangs in log/history and memory skyrockets

fields.description:
SourceTree has become unresponsive upon switching from the "Log / History" tab to the "File Status" tab

CPU usage is steadily around 25% (I have a 4-core CPU) and the main window is "greyed out"

Another possibly important factor is that I had two repositories open in SourceTree and tried to close the other repository's tab at the top right after attempting to switch to the "File Status" tab of the repository I was working with (I am just thinking it could have caused a deadlock or something like that)

Commit context menu -> Rebase -> Select first commit -> Edit Message -> Cancel

fields.description:
Any of the following will make Custom Actions more useful (from the Tools=>Options menu)

* reordering of custom actions
* associating an action with a specific bookmark/repo vs all bookmarks/repos

Please split this story as needed.
fields.summary: Custom action usability enhancements

fields.description:
SourceTree becomes inresponsive after clicking on the initial commit of the Microsoft's Roslyn project.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start SourceTree
2. Clone the https://git01.codeplex.com/roslyn repository
3. Choose the master branch on the history tab
4. Scroll down to the initial release
5. Click on the initial commit with the hash 3611ed356107 that was made at Mar 18 11:47 PM (see attached image: source_tree_roslyn_crash)

After these steps SourceTree becomes inresponsive and it needs to be shut down manually.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when trying to open initial commit of the Roslyn project

fields.description: When you create a new Mercurial repository in Bitbucket, you are greeted with a page that has a "Clone in SourceTree" button.  When you click that button, it launches SourceTree, with the "URL Actions" dialog up, and the "Clone New" tab up.  On this dialog, there is a "Checkout Branch" section, which is set to "default", and cannot be changed.  When you hit the "Clone" button, the clone fails with, "abort: unknown branch 'default'!"  If I try to clone it from the "Hosted Repositories" panel, I have the same problem.  The only way to clone the repository is to go to "Add Repository" and enter the appropriate "Source Path."
fields.summary: Bitbucket's "Clone in SourceTree" button fails for new Mercurial repos

fields.description: Accidentally dragged a project bookmark from one of my bookmark folders to another. SourceTree then crashed and closed itself. Haven't yet been able to reproduce it. Not sure what else to say.
fields.summary: Folders cause crash

fields.description: Today was announced that Git contains "A critical Git security vulnerability". It would be nice that in the options panel of sourcetree on the tab git, the button "Update embedded git" downloads the latest version of git (1.9.5). https://github.com/blog/1938-git-client-vulnerability-announced
fields.summary: Update Embedded git version

fields.description: the soft is usually crashed.
fields.summary: the soft is usually crashed.

fields.description: Grouping branches beneath a folder is really useful, however, can the branch names within a folder be sorted using [natural sorting|http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Natural_sorting], please?  Thanks!
fields.summary: Sort Branch Names with Natural Sorting

fields.description:
SourceTree constantly refreshing the log view (commit information section) making it very hard to review information about commits.
The view is refreshed all the time even when there is not change in the file system.
If I disable the 'refresh automatically when files change' option in the settings screen the constant refresh is stopped but then I have to refresh manually.
fields.summary: SourceTree constantly refreshing log view

fields.description:
Checking out to an old branch/tag (meaning that there have been many commits, possibly thousands, between the old branch's HEAD and the current HEAD) may rise memory consumption to very high levels (up to 2GB in our case) and causes SourceTree to stall for minutes.

This can be reproduced too by clicking on the branch/tag in order to find it in the tree (so it's not really necessary to checkout in order to cause this behavior).
fields.summary: Checking out to an old branch/tag may rise memory consumption to very high levels

fields.description:
We work on a large project, often have 6-8 hotfixes we need to merge (it's not much) but when doing merge it's confusing that a single change in a character (from upper-to lower case) or single char inserting/removing is shown as removing an entire line and adding a new.

If code blocks are modified (tabified f.e.) the entire block is removed a new block is added, instead of just modifying the proper characters...

Please check out how *SmartGit* merging work, or check out *Meld* (meldmerge.org).

Anyhow this is only an imporvement, a major one - but the performance problems (UI hangs / processes an event for 5-15sec) is more annoying.

We like SourceTree, but miss the performance and the advanced merging/staging...
fields.summary: Better staging/merge tool

fields.description:
We (team of 10 developers) use SourceTree with a large repository with tens of thousands of files where we often branch and merge.

When we first started to use SouceTree (around v1.5.2), everybody was thrilled and satisfied. However, since the diff viewer and the new file status view were introduced in v1.6 most of us experience unpleasant lags (multiple seconds) and frequent hangs where we have to kill the application. Although, the new views look much nicer, they seem to update more often and to use considerably more time and memory to do so. 

Many of us are now frustrated up to the point where look into alternative clients or revert to the old 1.5 versions. We do appreciate SourceTree and all the work you guys have put into it and we'd love to continue using it. Please consider to improve the performance of the 1.6 versions before you add more features.

Related issue: SRCTREEWIN-1910
fields.summary: SourceTree frequently hangs, performance issues

fields.description:
Application crashes (Not responding) when committing changes of any kind 2000+ files at once.
Using git-flow >  start hotfix> locally from windows explorer > delete entire wordpress directory>  unstaged changes appear> then stage changes >
enter commit message > commit to local hotfix branch >
Application crashes/ shows as "Not Responding" even after about 1.5 hours. 
I can do this using git bash Or VS Team Explorer no problem. However, we use git with SourceTree as a company because of how easy it is to pick up and for the git-flow integration. When those changes are pulled by other team members Sourcetree will crash/NotRespond which stops development. 

moderate git knowledge, new to 1.6.11 using git-flow, long time user of sourcetree for git operations. 

suggestions?
fields.summary: Sourcetree v 1.6.11 crashes on windows 8.1 when committing a large directory

fields.description:
I did a commit of some node_modules, and now when I return to the project, ST will hang and memory will continue to grow.
I have a dump file if needed.
I cannot use ST at all, unless I remove the opentabs.xml and restart. Otherwise ST remains unresponsive.
Let me know if I can give you any logs or dumpfile. 
This fails in beta.12001 as well.
I reset the last commit:
git reset --hard HEAD~1
And it started up, but when I clicked on the commit (that I had pushed to origin) it froze again. 
The commit was 5977 files. From:
git show --pretty="format:" --name-only 9425c2ab95e01b4dd4371414d28d4f1610439857

However, after reversing it and doing an npm install, windows says:
10,782 files and 104MB on disk (maybe something happened to the commit?)


Also, did I mention that while stash is hung (grayed out), it increases in memory? it is over 2GB right now and growing at a rate of 286,196K/minute (at least for a single one minute sample)
fields.summary: Hangs and Grows memory after large commit

fields.description:
Attempted to pull from origin to local machine. Received this error:

error: unable to create file ordering/public/images/logos/school-{$school->id}.jpeg (Invalid argument)

Because someone had committed a file named school-{$school->id}.jpeg .

Attempted to pull a second time, and received an error because many of the files pulled down would be overwritten by merge.

Removed all untracked files and discarded all pending changed files, attempted to pull a third time. Application Crashed. 

Started application again, application immediately crashes. Cannot start application.
fields.summary: After an error occured on pull, sourcetree crashed and crashes on start-up

fields.description:
We make use of git-media (https://github.com/vitei/git-media) to store large files outside of the git object database and retrieve them automatically in the clean/smudge filters.  Usually, this works fine, but occasionally SourceTree reports that it couldn't find the `git-media` executable (see attached screenshot).

Discarding the message and then refreshing usually works.  Sometimes it takes a few refreshes.  These failed filters can cause unwanted side-effects, such as marking files as modified when in fact they haven't been, requiring us to manually discard the changes -- so the issue is worse than just an annoying error message.

It's as if the PATH environment variable has been temporarily modified, or for some reason git/SourceTree have temporarily "forgotten" the location of git-media.  I have confirmed that the executable is locatable in both the system and the user PATH environment variables.  Unfortunately the problem is usually so fleeting that further research has proved difficult -- by the time we click through the error message the problem has resolved itself.  I am fairly certain that the problem is not with `git-media` specifically, but would happen when running any filter that requires git to run an executable/script located in PATH.
fields.summary: Temporarily unable to find filters located in Windows PATH

fields.description:
I was in d:\ws\build-configuration and had launched SourceTree.  I exited SourceTree, and attempted to delete d:\ws\build-configuration, but it failed because a handle was opened by pageant.exe.  I exited pageant.exe cleanly, and then tried to start SourceTree in the d:\ws directory, and it then asked me to file a bug.

The log is attached.
fields.summary: SourceTree failed to start after killing pageant.exe

fields.description:
Crashes as switching repositories (via tabs)
It doesn't crash every time, but it has occurred several times before I reported it.  See attached log.
fields.summary: Crash when switch repositories

fields.description: I'm really sorry to duplicate this bug, but I wasn't sure how to bring it to anyone's attention otherwise. This is biting us with non-technical users (artists), and is not trivially easy to work around (unless I've missed something). It's sucking up a fair bit of support time, so I'd like it to be considered a higher priority than "Trivial" if possible.

fields.description: SourceTree for Windows crashed after reporting that I should not push to remote from local, but should pull from local into remote
fields.summary: Crash on Push to BitBucket

fields.description:
If you create a new feature in Git Flow, and name it with a dash in the name

Like: {{feature/with/inthename}}

Then it will be displayed in a way that I did not expect in the left pane. It seems like the first dash is interpreted as a limited, and the first part of the name is handled as a folder, and the rest of the name as the actual branch.

Finishing the feature however seems to work just fine. The same goes for the branch Log/History view, here the branchname is displayed as it should.

See attached dump.
fields.summary: git flow feature with a dash in it is displayed as a folder in the pane

fields.description: If there is no text to save, there is no point in popping up the "Replace commit text?" dialog.  It just gets in the way.
fields.summary: "Amend latest commit" causes unnecessary confirmation dialog if commit text is empty.

fields.description:
I have about 20 Git repositories and I have never used Mercurial, but Microsoft Process Explorer is showing SourceTree is often calling CreateFile for Mercurial paths that do not exist.

For example, my Git repository is c:\git\foo\.git, then I see SourceTree calling CreateFile for c:\git\foo\.git and then c:\git\foo\.hg.  The latter always gives FILE NOT FOUND---about 20 times per minute.

I noticed this because sometimes SourceTree is slow and freezing, and while this .hg step may not be the only or major cause, perhaps removing this step can help.  What makes this slower is most of my repositories are on network drives.
fields.summary: SourceTree unnecessarily calls CreateFile for .hg files in Git repositories
